content:
• Wednesday, June 8, 2016

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: EAT +6.9%. EVHC +5.1%. NPTN +4.7%. ABM +4.0%. HRB +3.5%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: INSM -20.0%. RH -18.4%. PSG -13.5%. THM -8.0%. VALE -4.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • OREX

    Orexigen up over 50% on favorable Contrave patent ruling

    • Nano cap Orexigen Therapeutics (NASDAQ:OREX) was up 52% today on a 6x surge in volume in response to its announcement of a favorable Markman ruling related to the company and Takeda's (OTCPK:TKPHF)(TKPYY) Contrave patent infringement litigation against Actavis (NYSE:AGN).
    • A Markman or claims construction ruling, is a pretrial hearing in which a judge determines the meaning of the disputed patent claims in patent litigation. In this case, Judge Richard Andrews adopted Orexigen's proposed constructions for the majority of the disputed claims, a big win for the company and making it significantly more difficult for Actavis to prevail.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM | 5 Comments
  • RH

    Soft guidance hits Restoration Hardware

    • Comparable brand revenue 4% for Restoration Hardware (NYSE:RH) to help contribute to the 8% gain in total revenue.
    • The company missed estimates on the bottom line in Q1 and issued a warning on the full year.
    • Profit drags include costs associated with RH Modern production delays, investments in customer experience, the timing of recognizing certain membership revenue, and a "more aggressive approach" to rationalizing inventory.
    • Looking ahead to Q2, Restoration Hardware expects full year revenue of $505M to $520M vs. $532M consensus and EPS of $0.28 to $0.33 vs. $0.80 consensus. The outlook for the full year is also lowered.
    • RH -12.6% AH to $31.51.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:22 PM | 10 Comments
  • AMSG

    AmSurg/Envision Healthcare in merger talks

    • CNBC reports that AmSurg (NASDAQ:AMSG) and Envision Healthcare (NYSE:EVHC) are in talks to combine. A deal could be announced as early as next week.
    • In after hours trading, AMSG is up 3% and EVHC is ahead 5%.
    • Update: Supposedly, the deal is done according to market chatter on June 15. Details are scarce at the moment, though.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:09 PM
  • FNJN

    Finjan blasts off after settling with Proofpoint

    • Finjan (FNJN +13.9%) has settled its infringement suit against security software firm Proofpoint (PFPT +1.6%). As part of the deal, Finjan will receive $10.9M in cash via three payments: A $4.3M up-front payment, a $3.3M payment due on or before Jan. 4, 2017, and a $3.3M payment due on or before Jan. 3, 2018. Other deal terms are confidential.
    • With Finjan sporting a $35M market cap going into day, shares have soared on the news. The company has also sued a number of other security tech firms. A $39.5M jury award was obtained last year in a suit against security hardware/software provider Blue Coat.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:51 PM
  • DCP

    DCP Midstream downgraded at Jefferies, which sees

    • DCP Midstream Partners (DPM -2.5%) is downgraded to Hold from Buy with a $35 price target at Jefferies on valuation, as units have appreciated 53% YTD, including a 140% surge from February lows.
    • DPM's Q1 distributable cash flow exceeded estimates at $165M, driven by lower than expected maintenance capex, higher than expected unconsolidated affiliate distributions and MVC receipts worth $2M.
    • The firm also does not expect DPM to be able to cover its distribution to the end of the year.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM | 10 Comments
  • RIO

    Rio Tinto's expected 20% IRR on Oyu Tolgoi exaggerated, Bernstein says

    • Rio Tinto's (RIO +2.2%) anticipated returns from its $5.3B development of the Oyu Tolgoi underground copper and gold mine in Mongolia are exaggerated, Bernstein Research says.
    • The firm questions Rio's expected 20% internal rate of return on the underground project, based on the long lead-time to full production and potential risks, including political shifts and the challenges of block cave mining.
    • "The project has significant technical and non-technical risks that could derail the investment case, even if copper prices increase to above $3.0 per pound as Rio expects (and, indeed, so do we)," the firm says.
    • Bernstein's conclusion was based on an assessment it commissioned from Rio's former general manager of valuation.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:15 PM | 3 Comments

  • Technology - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: BLIN +62%. HMNY +18%. FNJN +13%. CBAK-OLD +13%. WPCS +15%.
    • Losers: MTSC -11%. NEON -8%. SMI -6%. OTC:VLTC -5%. LEDS -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM
  • SUN

    Sunoco downgraded at Jefferies, which foresees distribution cut

    • Sunoco (SUN -8.6%) is downgraded to Underperform from Hold with a $23 price target, cut from $35, at Jefferies, which says escalating leverage will lead to a distribution cut by year-end to remain in compliance with credit covenants and restore its financial health.
    • Jefferies says that in the absence of $40M in margins from opportunistic supply and trading - which the company does not expect to persist - SUN's normalized Q1 distributable cash flow would have totaled $70M, which implies coverage of only 0.7x rather than the 1.18x reported for the quarter.
    • SUN condensed an initial 27-month dropdown schedule into just 18 by relying heavily on debt to fund its ~$5.7B of purchases, which left its leverage stretched and liquidity tight, the firm says.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 20 Comments
  • LC

    LendingClub shrugs off downgrade

    • Down earlier after FBR threw in the towel with a downgrade to Market Perform from Outperform, Lending Club (LC +0.9%) has bounced higher in afternoon action.
    • Analyst Bob Ramsey expects a significant drop in demand for loans and cut his 2016 and 2017 EPS outlooks to $0.15 and $0.20, respectively, from $0.25 and $0.40.
    • Leaning against the FBR downgrade was an upgrade to Market Perform from KBW. There was also last night's story about ousted CEO Renaud Laplanche trying to line up financing to take LC private, though regulators might have different ideas.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:42 PM | 2 Comments

  • Round trip for gold

    • Gold's 1.3% advance today to $1,263 per ounce brings it back to the level it was at on May 18 - the day hawkish FOMC minutes all-of-a-sudden put a June rate hike on the table. The metal subsequently tumbled nearly all the way to $1,200 at May's end.
    • More dovish remarks from Fed speakers led by Janet Yellen, along with last week's sluggish employment report have served as catalysts for the big June rebound.
    • Also at work is ETF demand for gold, writes Chris Dieterich - it acts like a "slow-moving train" supporting rallies on the way up. The GLD, he says, has taken in $9.3B in fresh money this year - that's more than 60% above the second place iShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond ETF.
    • ETFs: GLD, IAU, PHYS, SGOL, UGL, DGP, GTU, UGLD, GLL, DZZ, GLDI, OUNZ, DGL, DGZ, DGLD, GYEN, GEUR, UBG, QGLDX
     
     
     
     
    | 2:33 PM | 31 Comments
  • CVE

    Wildfires force Cenovus, Canadian Natural to shut Pelican Lake facilities

    • The wildfires in Alberta are again affecting crude oil production, as Cenovus Energy (CVE -2.8%) and Canadian Natural Resources (CNQ -3.2%) evacuate oil facilities near Pelican Lake.
    • Flames advanced yesterday to within 1 km of CVE's main Pelican Lake complex, forcing the company to shut down its heavy oil plant and evacuate 118 staff; the site produced ~23K bbl/day of heavy oil during Q1.
    • CNQ also temporarily halted some production at its 49K bbl/day Pelican Lake operations and evacuated non-essential staff.
    • Further north, oil sands producers have begun restarting operations after the fires forced last month's shutdown of more than 1M bbl/day of production in the Fort McMurray region; ConocoPhillips (COP +0.2%) says 10% of its wells have been activated at its 60K bbl/day Surmont project, with most of its ~700 employees expected onsite by the end of this week.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:24 PM | 3 Comments

  • Energy/Materials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: GEVO +82%. NADL +27%. AKS +19%. ASM +14%. SID +14%.
    • Losers: ENBL -10%. SUN -9%. CWEI -8%. AREX -8%. GSI -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:00 PM | 8 Comments
  • TRGP

    Targa Resources cut to Hold at Jefferies on valuation

    • Targa Resources (TRGP -3.7%) is downgraded to Hold from Buy with a $45 price target at Jefferies, which cites valuation and the potential for further pressure on margins.
    • Jefferies says TRGP's Q1 EBITDA of $265M easily beat its estimate of $222M and Wall Street expectations of $255M, and distributable cash flow of $178M also came in well above the firm's estimate of $124M.
    • The firm expects TRGP to keep its quarterly cash dividend unchanged at $0.91/share through 2018 with ~5% annual growth resuming in 2019.
    • TRGP has surged 72% YTD, including a 91% rip higher since its February lows.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:57 PM | 5 Comments

  • Financials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM

    • Gainers: AHP +28%. ATLC +8%. MTR +7%. YRD +6%. BSBR +5%.
    • Losers: XIN -5%. GARS -4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM
  • ENLK

    EnLink to build Permian Basin crude gathering system

    • EnLink Midstream Partners (ENLK -3.6%) and EnLink Midstream LLC (ENLC -3.5%) announce plans to construct a crude oil gathering system in Texas' Permian Basin.
    • The partners say they will invest $70M-$80M in the Greater Chickadee crude oil gathering project, which will include more than 150 miles of high- and low-pressure pipelines that will transport crude volumes to several major market outlets and other hub centers in the Midland, Tex., area.
    • The companies say the initial phase of the project will be operational in H2 of this year with full service expected early next year.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM
  • COF

    Capital One lower after downgrade

    • An outlier to the downside among the credit card names today is Capital One (COF -1.2%) after Sterne Agee downgrades to Underperform from Neutral.
    • Cited by analyst Henry Coffey are ongoing business line challenges, rising credit costs thanks to energy, lower spreads in auto lending, and long-term branch structural issues.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM
  • OBE

    Reuters: Penn West assets attracting interest from several bidders

    • Penn West Petroleum (PWE +9.9%) has received at least four bids from companies for its Viking light oil assets which could fetch more than C$500M ($395M), Reuters reports.
    • Bidders include Raging River Exploration (OTC:RRENF), Crescent Point Energy (NYSE:CPG), Whitecap Resources (OTCPK:SPGYF) and Teine Energy, according to the report; all four bidders have a presence in the Viking area of Saskatchewan, a light oil region that is attractive to energy producers because of its low costs to recover crude and competitive production costs.
    • PWE's Viking assets, which produce nearly 20K boe/day, are important to the company, and its willingness to sell them highlights the company's financial pressure over its large debt burden.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:49 PM | 62 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: OTC:BSPM +261%. BLIN +64%. SPU +30%. AHP +29%. NADL +29%. BLPH +29%. WPCS +27%. ULBI +25%. CIDM +20%. SHLO +18%.
    • Losers: FCSC -39%. PAY -27%. CATB -25%. FLXN -13%. EAC -12%. OTC:CALI -13%. CLWT -12%. VBLT -11%. CLNT -10%. ENBL -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:46 PM | 1 Comment
  • IMNP

    Immune Pharma files patent for orally available mAb for GI inflammation and NASH; shares up 43%

    • Nano cap Immune Pharmaceuticals (OTCQB:IMNP +43%) heads north on almost a 5x surge in volume in response to its announcement that it has filed a provisional patent, together with The Hadassah Medical Organization, on the oral use of anti-eotaxin monoclonal antibodies, including lead product candidate bertilimumab, for the treatment of inflammatory diseases of the liver and GI tract.
    • According to Yaron Ilan, Professor of Medicine at Hebrew University's Hadassah Hospital, oral bertilimumab may have potential in treating patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) who have high levels of eotaxin-1, a protein that plays a role in immune responses and is associated with the proliferation of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell that rapidly increases in inflammatory conditions. In an animal model, oral administration of a non-absorbable murine anti-eotaxin-1 antibody demonstrated biological activity in the gut and produced a systemic immunomodulatory effect that improved immune-mediated hepatitis.
    • The company is currently evaluating parenteral (injection or infusion) bertilimumab in a Phase 2a study in ulcerative colitis. Phase 2 studies in NASH will follow.
    • Biologic drugs, specifically monoclonal antibodies, are typically administered via IV infusion. Oral administration has obvious advantages but overcoming the action of enzymes in the gut that break down proteins (proteases) will be challenging.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:18 PM
  • GIS

    General Mills' strategic alignment with Organic Valley

    • General Mills (GIS -0.1%) announced a strategic partnership with the largest organic cooperative in the U.S. that will help about 20 dairy farms add around 3,000 acres to organic dairy production over the next three years.
    • This strategic alignment will build General Mills' relationships with the organic farmers who will be supporting its yogurt operating unit in the U.S., which includes brands like Yoplait, Annie's, Liberté and Mountain High.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:03 PM | 1 Comment

  • Consumer Goods - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: SPU +26%. SKUL +16%.
    • Losers: PAY -28%. OXM -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:01 PM
  • RDS.A

    Shell upgraded at Evercore ISI on new shareholder return philosophy

    • Royal Dutch Shell (RDS.A +2.2%) is higher after Evercore ISI upgrades shares to Buy from Hold with a $64 price target, applauding the company's decision to embrace a strategy that values shareholder returns over growth.
    • Evercore says Shell's previous "growth at the expense of returns" approach caused the company's return on capital employed and its economic value added fell 75% over the past decade or so, and the firm believes investors will assign the stock a higher valuation if Shell can successfully carry out the new strategy.
    • The firm says the change differentiates Shell from its supermajor peers, adding that while value creation is harder to achieve, accountability, organizational effectiveness and shareholder value stand to increase considerably.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:58 AM | 4 Comments
  • PBR

    Petrobras begins sale process of LNG terminals; overall output rises 5%

    • Petrobras (PBR +9.3%) says it has begun the bidding process to sell its liquefied natural gas terminals in Rio de Janeiro and Ceará, along with the thermoelectric power plants associated with these terminals.
    • The Rio facility has a regasification capacity of 20M cm/day, while the Ceará terminal has 7M cm/day capacity.
    • PBR hopes to divest ~$15B in non-core assets by year-end in an effort to pare down its $130B debt burden.
    • Separately, PBR says its overall production in May rose 5% from April to 2.83M boe/day, with average oil output rising 6% to 2.24M bbl/day for the company's fifth largest rate of production on record.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:32 AM | 9 Comments

  • Healthcare - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 11:00 am

    • Gainers: OTC:BSPM +96%. OTC:ECTE +11%. EVAR +9%. NLNK +7%. GI +6%.
    • Losers: FCSC -40%. CATB -26%. FLXN -12%. TRXC -10%. VBLT -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:00 AM
  • BSPM

    Trading in Biostar Pharma halted due to volatility, trading resumes

    • Trading in nano cap Biostar Pharmaceuticals (OTC:BSPM +107.3%) was temporarily halted this morning due to volatility. Shares have more than doubled on a 50x surge in volume (turnover of ~500K shares) on no news.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:58 AM | 1 Comment
  • WMB

    Williams warns it will cut dividend if Energy Transfer deal fails

    • While committing to pay a $0.64/share dividend for the current quarter, Williams Cos. (WMB +0.1%) warns it would cut its dividend in the next quarter if a deal to sell itself to Energy Transfer Equity (ETE +2.2%) falls through.
    • WMB, which reiterates its commitment to closing the ETE deal, says it has not determined the amount of any dividend cut but that it "could be material."
    • WMB shareholders are scheduled to vote June 27 on the deal, which ETE has been trying to restructure or exit altogether.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:47 AM | 104 Comments
  • BHR

    Ashford Prime confirms offer, will study

    • Confirming receipt of an unsolicited proposal to buy the company from The Weisman Group - a real estate investment firm based out of Sherman Oaks, CA - Ashford Prime (AHP +35.3%) says it intends to carefully review the offer.
    • To review, Ashford Prime was spun out of Ashford Trust (AHT +2.1%) just less than three years ago. The performance of the stock price since has been underwhelming (off about 50%).
    • The company - after completing a strategic review earlier this year - now is engaged in a proxy fight with activist investor Sessa Capital.
    • Previously: Ashford Prime takeover offer at near 100% premium (June 8)
    • The stock just came off trading halt, and is now up 35% to $15.30 per share. Weisman's offer is for $20.25. External manager Ashford, Inc (AINC -1.6%).
     
     
     
     
    | 10:19 AM | 9 Comments
  • AKS

    AK Steel +10% after Credit Suisse upgrade; other steel stocks gain

    • AK Steel (AKS +10.5%) surges more than 10% as Credit Suisse upgrades shares to Outperform from Neutral with a $7 price target, doubled from $3.50, after the firm increases its U.S. steel price deck.
    • Credit Suisse says it remains "very bullish" on the U.S. steel industry, and its new supply/demand model for the U.S. flat rolled market indicates continued deficits for value add sheet into Q3, supporting prices well above fair value levels.
    • The firm raises its price targets on all steel stocks in its coverage universe except Commercial Metals (CMC +1.9%), owing to rebar spread risks.
    • Steel stocks (SLX +2.8%) are broadly higher in early trading: X +6.8%, MT +3.9%, STLD +3.8%, NUE +2.4%, WOR +1.5%, ZEUS +1.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:18 AM | 9 Comments
  • BHR

    Ashford Prime takeover offer at near 100% premium

    • The Weisman Group discloses a roughly 5% stake in Ashford Prime (AHP) and a letter sent to CEO Monty Bennett offering to buy the whole company for $1.48B, or $20.25 per share (vs. last night's close of $11.32).
    • The stock remains halted, up 29% on the session to $14.76.
    • Ashford, Inc. (AINC +0.8%)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:02 AM
  • WMT

    No fear on Wal-Mart despite mind-blowing size

    • A profile on Wal-Mart (WMT -0.1%) posted on Quartz adds a little context on just how big the Bentonville company has now become.
    • Wal-Mart's revenue haul of $482B last year was more than Amazon, Apple, and Microsoft combined.
    • The number of weekly shoppers at a Wal-Mart store is up to 260M.
    • Wal-Mart is also the world's third largest employer, trailing only the U.S. Department of Defense and China's People's Liberation Army.
    • Despite the gargantuan size of Wal-Mart, analysts and investors see a rational approach from management. Earlier this week, Jefferies said the pace of international store growth and pruning of square footage in the U.S. will help profitability. That view was issued after Wal-Mart casually said it aims to add $60B in sales over the next three years.
    • Only four analysts out of 31 rate Wal-Mart at Sell/Underweight.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:56 AM | 10 Comments
  • EQR

    Jefferies turns cautious on multi-family

    • Equity Residential (EQR -1%), AvalonBay Communities (AVB -1.1%), and Essex Property Trust (ESS -0.5%) are all downgraded to Hold from Buy at Jefferies.
    • With market caps of $13B-$23B, these three are the apartment sector giants by a wide margin. They tend to play in the high-priced markets on the coasts (Essex is all West Coast).
    • Equity Residential made big news late last year when it sold a big chunk of its portfolio - and when Sam Zell sells, it's worth paying attention to. The company made more news last week when it cut guidance thanks to weakness in San Francisco and New York (though management played this down at a conference yesterday).
    • Other sector names: Post Properties (PPS +0.1%), UDR (UDR -0.8%), Aimco (AIV -0.5%), Camden Property (CPT -1%), Mid-America (MAA -0.3%), Investors Real Estate (IRET +1.6%), Independence Realty (IRT +0.4%), Monogram Residential (MORE -0.5%), NexPoint (NXRT), Preferred Apartment (APTS +0.6%), Bluerock Residential (BRG -0.2%)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:49 AM | 9 Comments
  • HALO

    Halozyme improves cash position with debt refinance; shares up 2% premarket

    • Halozyme (NASDAQ:HALO) inks a new financing agreement with Oxford Finance LLC and Silicon Valley Bank under which it borrowed $55M at 8.25% to refinance existing long-term debt. The new facility allows interest-only payments for the first 18 months, followed by principal and interest payments until maturity on January 1, 2021.
    • The deal should increase the company's cash balance by $22M both this year and in 2017. The company has the option to borrow an additional $15M in Q2 2017 at prime + 4.75%.
    • As of March 31, Halozyme's quick assets totaled ~$239M.
    • Shares are up 2% premarket on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:28 AM | 2 Comments

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers as of 9:10 am

    • Gainers: BLIN +52%. FNJN +46%. AHP +29%. HMNY +25%. UEC +9%. GPL +8%. PLAY +7%. AKS +7%. AG +7%. AEHR +7%. EXK +6%. DRYS +6%. LC +6%. HMY +6%. IAG +6%. ORIG +6%. AU +5%. GFI +5%. SSRI +5%. NGD +5%. GORO 5%.
    • Losers: PAY -30%. FLXN -12%. ASC -11%. RMP -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:16 AM | 1 Comment
  • TGT

    Target higher after dividend hike

    • Shares of Target (NYSE:TGT) are on the move after the company fired off a pretty sizable dividend increase. The new yield of 3.5% compares favorably in the retail sector.
    • Last quarter, Target returned $336M to shareholders in dividend payments and invested almost $900M in share repurchase.
    • Previously: Target declares $0.60 dividend (June 8)
    • TGT +1.11% premarket to $68.98.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:14 AM | 25 Comments
  • FCSC

    Fibrocell's lead product candidate flunks mid-stage study; shares slump 47% premarket

    • Thinly traded nano cap Fibrocell Science (NASDAQ:FCSC) is down 47% premarket, albeit on only 3,800 shares, in response to its announcement that its Phase 2 clinical trial assessing lead product candidate azficel-T for the treatment of vocal cord scarring resulting in chronic/severe dysphonia (difficulty in speaking) failed to beat placebo. As a result, the company will cease development and focus its resources on gene therapy candidate FCX-007, being developed in collaboration with Intrexon (NASDAQ:XON).
    •  Azficel-T is a personalized gene therapy based on the patient's own cells called fibroblasts, the most common cell in the skin and connective tissue.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:09 AM | 5 Comments
  • PLAY

    Dave & Buster's busts through 52-week high

    • Dave & Buster's (NASDAQ:PLAY) trades higher after the company raised its outlook for full-year revenue. Analysts on Wall Street digging into the Q1 report found plenty to like.
    • Jefferies: The ability of Dave & Buster's to offset labor inflation and a tough Texas market is noted. A price target of $50 is lined up.
    • BMO: The firm notes that another revision higher in the forecast for comparable-store sale growth could be seen down the road with only Q1 factored into yesterday's guidance.
    • Piper Jaffray: Brand modernization is seen as a key driver of D&B's momentum. Shares are rated at Overweight and assigned a new price target of $51.
    • Previously: Dave & Buster's higher after strong sales growth (June 7)
    • PLAY +5.11% premarket to $44.00 which marks a 52-week high.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:47 AM | 1 Comment
  • DERM

    Dermira prices $126M equity offering; shares down 6% premarket

    • Thinly traded Dermira (NASDAQ:DERM) is off 6% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement that it has priced its public offering of 4.5M shares of common stock at $28 a share. Underwriters over-allotment is an additional 675K shares.
    • Yesterday's close was $30.21.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:46 AM
  • FLXN

    Flexion Therapeutics initiates $60M equity offering; shares down 11% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap Flexion Therapeutics (NASDAQ:FLXN) is off 11% premarket on modest volume in response to its announcement that it has commenced a $60M public offering of common stock. Price, volume and terms have yet to be released.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:40 AM | 2 Comments
  • PLCM

    Polycom gets buyout offer from P-E firm, challenging Mitel deal

    • Polycom (NASDAQ:PLCM) +2.4% premarket after disclosing that it received a revised offer from a P-E firm to take it private at $12.25/share.
    • PLCM says the unidentified buyer's proposal comprises $650M of equity financing and $950M of debt financing.
    • In April, PLCM had agreed to be acquired by Mitel Networks (NASDAQ:MITL) for $1.96B in cash and stock; based on yesterday’s close, the deal values PLCM at $12/share, but it valued the company at $13.44/share when the deal was first announced.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:40 AM | 2 Comments
  • PAY

    Analysts sent scrambling after VeriFone's outlook disappoints

    • Pacific Crest downgrades VeriFone Systems (NYSE:PAY) to Sector Weight from Overweight due to the lowered outlook issued by the company.
    • The investment firm sees fair value of $22 to $24 based off of a multiple of 11X to 12X over projected earnings per share.
    • Wedbush lowers its price target to $30.
    • Compass Point shifts to a Neutral rating from Buy.
    • Barclays lowers its rating Equal Weight from Overweight.
    • Goldman Sachs drops its PT to $28 and Credit Suisse moves to a $24 PT.
    • Previously: VeriFone craters after FQ2 EPS miss and weak guidance; NCR slips (June 7)
    • PAY -29.13% premarket to $20.00.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:34 AM | 4 Comments
  • GEF

    More on Greif's FQ2

    • Greif (NYSE:GEF) reports revenue growth was flat Y/Y in FQ2 after adjusting the impact of divestiture and currency translation.
    • Revenue by segment: Rigid industrial packaging & services: $589.6M (-11.6%); Paper packaging & services: $167.2M (+4.2%); Flexible products & services: $76.2M (-7.1%); Land management: $6.6M (-4.3%).
    • Gross margin rate improved 90 bps to 20.7%.
    • Adjusted operating margin rate increased 150 bps to 9.4%.
    • Adjusted EBITDA expanded 4.9% Y/Y to $109.6M.
    • The company expects adjusted EPS in the range of $2.20 to $2.46 for FY2016.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:05 AM
  • LULU

    Lululemon Athletica down post Q1 results

    • Lululemon (NASDAQ:LULU) reports comparable-store sales rose 3% (+5% on a constant dollar basis) in Q1.
    • Direct to consumer revenue grew 17.6% to $97.6M (+18% on a constant dollar basis).
    • Gross profit rate squeezed 300 bps to 48.3%.
    • SG&A expenses rate increased 410 bps to 36.6%.
    • Operating income rate decreased 450 bps to 11.6%.
    • Inventory expanded 21% Y/Y to $286.23M.
    • Store count +10 Q/Q to 373.
